preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: What started as an inquiry regarding the adoption, use and support for Synchronous Distance Learning Programs evolved, to me, into an exploration of the people and the tools that we use to deliver Distance Learning, both Synchronous and Asynchronous and where the technology and people are going in this Brave New World.

Even though I have been working on Distance Learning for 10 years I had never really realized the breadth and depth necessary for online courses, training workshops to be delivered successfully. From accessibility expert who ensure that the content is usable by all students, to the instructional designers and trainers who make sure that faculty are up to speed with the tools they are going to use, to the system administrators who make sure that the system is reliable and doesn't crash when you least expect it.

That's why I decided to go for breadth first and then, if possible, go for depth. There is too much to cover in order to really understand Distance Learning to really go much in depth about it. I hope that I have done justice to the material I have covered.

partintro.para: The survey described below was commissioned by CSU, Chico as an environmental scan for Distance Learning tools and support models. as indicated in the report introduction, CSU, Chico is starting to look at new technologies and methods to support Distance Learning programs.

The purpose of the survey is not to interpret the data but to raises questions and issues for future research and discussion. We are too early in the research process to be able to draw any substantive conclusions at this point of the process. However it is useful to know what other schools are doing and have contact information to pursue further questions or for additional research.

sect1.title: Introduction and Rationale
sect1.para: No one wants to work in a vacuum. CSU, Chico has used the same basic technology setup to deliver synchronous online instruction since 2000 when the satellite program was transitioned to an online format. In the mean time technology has progressed at an accelerated rate... where in 2000 there were a few vendors now there are several. Tools have been developed to both support and augment the synchronous tools used.

The survey grew up of a need to evaluate what other schools are doing in terms of synchronous distance learning tools and how these tools are being supported by the campuses. Whatever the reasons for having skipped a technological generation are; now CSU, Chico needs to play catch up. The information gathered in this survey will inform later steps and stages in our new Distance Learning tools selection process, support models and procedures and, eventually, lead to a model that will take CSU, Chico to a leadership position in Distance Learning.

sect1.title: Methodology and Survey Development
sect1.para: When developing the methodology it was decided that a survey was the best tool to conduct this project. Because surveys are static instruments it was also decided to request contact information for potential follow up questions. The survey will certainly generate more questions than the data can answer. It has been made clear from the beginning to participants that, while their personally identifying information would be kept confidential, the researcher will contact those institutions whose information has generated new research questions.
The survey was broken into 4 distinct areas:

listitem.para: Informed Consent as required by the University's Human Subject Review Committee
Demographics about the respondent and their institution
Demographics about the respondent institution's Synchronous and Asynchronous courses, LMS Integration and the way in which the software used for Distance Learning was selected
Specific information about the respondent's Synchronous Distance Learning Software and its support model for both faculty and students

sect1.para:
Once the author had an initial version of the survey it was reviewed by several members of Academic Technologies and after several meetings the final version of the survey was completed and submitted to Human Subjects for review and approval. See
for some of the lessons learned in the development and administration of the survey instrument.

When the survey instrument was developed then the team had to decide how to deliver the instrument. The author briefly considered creating a PDF and sending it via email to potential respondents allowing them to self-select for completion of the survey. This was deemed impractical due to the number of responses expected. The Center for Excellence in Teaching and Learning (CELT) owns a license for Survey Monkey (
). Since the technology is available and it makes the collection of data more manageable it was decided to use Survey Monkey to administer the survey and collect the results.

The survey was originally sent to 5 lists with 2 additional groups (Community College Users and Community College Distance Learning Coordinators) being added later when the survey was forwarded to community college users and Distance Learning Coordinators. These additional groups of respondent explain the high percentage of respondents from Community Colleges.
The survey was sent originally to the following lists:

listitem.para:
IT Forum:
A list for instructional designers and people who work developing instruction, both in education and corporate settings.

Community of Academic Technology Staff:
A community for people who work in academic technologies, initially across the California State University System and now open for membership

New Media Center Technology Advisory Board (TAB):
Members-Only list for knowledge sharing among the members of the New Media Center Consortium

Educause:
General Member list for Educause

LCIN Steering Committee:
LCIN (Leading Campuses International Network) is a group of former WebCT Institute program members who have regrouped under the name LCIN for the purpose of "Advancing effective use of course technologies by connecting people with good ideasâ€¦" (taken from LCIN website)

sect1.para: The variety of groups the survey was sent to was deliberate. The team wanted to ensure responses that were as varied as possible. As mentioned above, when the chance was offered to have the survey forwarded to Community College users it was deemed a good opportunity to expand the base of respondents and to gather information towards future research.

sect2.title: Lessons Learned
sect2.para: No matter how careful you are in developing a survey there are always things that could have been done different to improve the survey's overall response rate.
Some of the specific issues include:

sect3.title: Clarification about the voluntary nature of the survey
sect3.para: For some of the respondents from the community colleges in particular there was a perception that they were required to complete the survey whether it applied to them or not. Some of the feedback seems to indicate that they were required to complete the survey regardless of what the informed consent statement indicates.

This may have had to do with the fact that for this particular group the survey originated from the Community College's Chancellors office and not directly from the authors of the survey and therefore carried a more authoritative message to those who received it
Future surveys should clearly indicate and request people who forward the survey indicate that participation in the survey is strictly voluntary.

sect3.title: Survey Clarity and Specific Language in Instructions
sect3.para: As clear as we thought we had made the survey there was still a lot of confusion as to who the target audience was and who should answer the survey. Some people passed it over to their Distance Learning coordinators and others completed the survey as best as they could.

Even among the Community College's Distance Learning Coordinators there was confusion as to what information the survey sought to gather. There was an email where a Distance Learning Coordinator who indicated that the answers just provided were of no use as survey material because the coordinator had not realized that were were requesting information about synchronous Distance Learning and his program was fully asynchronous. While not a generalized comment it calls into question the clarity of the instructions provided with the survey.

Our expectation when developing the survey was that people who received it but were not able to answer it would pass it along to whoever they thought would be able to complete it for their institution. This was not the case which probably accounts for the number of faculty who completed the survey. See
for respondents' role within their institutions.

sect3.title: Question Wording and Stating Quantities
sect3.para: In addition to the question about the clarity of the instructions there was some feedback regarding the wording of some of the questions, in particular those that requested distinction between synchronous and asynchronous Distance Learning courses.

Where we ask number of courses that are synchronous and asynchronous Distance Learning courses it may have been better to use percentages rather than number of courses to eliminate part of the confusion created by the wording of the questions.

We also assumed a level of understanding from our audience in terms of what the objectives of the survey were. There was a lot of confusion and it was clear in comments and direct feedback that this was not always the case

chapter.title: Literature Review on Distance Learning and Related Technologies

partintro.para: There are areas where further questions should be asked to get a better picture of what is happening out in the field

chapter.title: Who are our learners?
chapter.para: Before we really know what system to implement we need to know more about our learners. It is not enough to have an analysis of the student demographics but also of the way they learn and the way they relate to technology.

How do the studies in generational learning apply to our students? We are dealing with several generations of students and they each learn differently, how can we leverage those learning styles in our Distance Education programs?

chapter.title: Defining Distance Learning
chapter.para: In analyzing the responses to the survey there seems to be as many definitions of Distance Learning as there are institutions with Distance Learning programs. There are some commonalities; for example, all programs serve remote students and most, if not all, programs have a mediated component be it video conference, synchronous online meetings or asynchronous online discussions but is there a working definition of "Distance Learning"? And if there is, then is the definition the same as that of "e/E-Learning"?

A future area of research may include searching for working definitions of Distance Learning and consolidating them into one coherent definition of what Distance Learning is. This should help in program definition and technology adoption.

chapter.title: Synchronous versus Asynchronous Distance Learning
chapter.para: A large number of respondents indicated that their Distance Learning program was delivered asynchronously and therefore the survey did not apply to their situation. While we are only interested in synchronous tools for this particular survey we may want to follow up with those institutions who chose an asynchronous delivery model to ask these questions:

listitem.para: What drove the adoption of an asynchronous Distance Learning program?
What criteria was used in selecting asynchronous versus synchronous Distance Learning delivery?
How long ago was the decision made?
Would the decision change with currently available tools?

chapter.title: Available tools and technologies
chapter.para: As mentioned in the rationale section of this report, video and technologies applicable to Distance Learning have progressed tremendously in the last few years. New offerings both in the higher education and corporate markets have been offered since CSU, Chico decided to run what has evolved into Wimba Classroom.

What other tools are there that may be used to complement and supplement synchronous Distance Learning offerings? CSU, Chico currently uses Wimba Voice Tools for some audio-only synchronous activities. What other tools are available in the Market? How can we deploy these tools to better support a hybrid in-class and fully online model?

Authoring tools have also made progress in the last few years. Tools like Trivantis Lectora and Wimba Create are now available in the market. These tools allow for easy creation of content, either directly from Microsoft Word like the Wimba solution or from an intuitive interface like Lectora's. If this facilitates the work of faculty we should take a look at these tools and see if they can be implemented on campus

Simulation and demonstration tools are another area that is worth exploring. Tools like Adobe Captivate and Techsmith's Camtasia are available for purchase or licensing. They both allow users to create simulations or narrated guides using a computer interface that is already familiar to the user and that should facilitate the learning process by providing means to engage the content through different learning styles and at their leisure. Furthermore, the same technology can be used to provide additional activities for on-campus courses.

Further research should investigate how these new tools interact with each other and with our Learning Management System (LMS); how does the content authored with these tools display and interacts with the LMS and with each other.

We should investigate what tools are available for synchronous Distance Learning not just because the time is coming to evaluate new technologies for adoption but also because we need to be able to articulate to our constituents what is available to them and how we can expect to interact with new technologies.

chapter.title: Learning Objects, SCORM, IMS and content sharing
chapter.para: Research should be conducted both on the cultural change needed for sharing to work across the institution and the technologies and tools used to actually author and share the content.

Learning Objects, some times called Reusable Learning Objects, are small chunks of content that can be reused in multiple instances and in multiple modalities. For more definitions of learning objects see IEEE, Shepherd and Wiley 2000

SCORM (Shareable Content Object Reference Model) is a standard initially developed by the aviation industry as a way to facilitate the sharing of content among different vendors and in different modalities. You can build your content just as a series of linked HTML pages or as complex as a self-contained unit with quizzes, interactivity and ongoing feedback for the learner.

Faculty can use all the tools listed in
can be used to to author SCORM content or the content package can be created manually. We no longer have to develop content multiple times but can "build once, use anywhere". Furthermore you can move these SCORM packages from Blackboard to Moodle or Desire2Learn making system-wide collaboration possible and desirable.
Collaboration in terms of developing SCORM materials can be as simple as developing HTML or Flash content or as complex as assembling the SCORM package manually if it's needed.
IMS Global Consortium a family of educational technology specifications developed to promote the use of computers in education and the interoperability of LMS and other eLearning tools.
3 standard that are worth mentioning are:

listitem.para:
Content Packaging:
allows multiple content items to be packaged together and imported into an LMS or to a CD-ROM

Quiz and Test Interoperability (QTI):
allows quizzes and surveys to be packaged and shared among multiple courses across LMS

Common Cartridge:
still under development the common cartridge appears to be an aggregation of multiple course elements that can be ported to environments other than where they were created

chapter.para: Learning objects are not easy to develop and they require a lot of planning and development time but, if enough objects can be created the school should see a significant reduction in cost for subsequent terms as the objects no longer need to be re-created and can be reused.

chapter.title: Tool Accessibility
chapter.subtitle: Defining a standard way to test tools for accessibility

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: While there has been an emphasis in web accessibility for websites and the retrofitting of existing web content there hasn't been a consistent effort to test content creation tools for their creation of accessible content and how accessible the tools themselves are.

This project seeks to address these issues by providing both a methodology and a selection of tools to test. It also seeks to create awareness regarding testing methodologies and how they can be applied to evaluating technology.

sect1.title: Problem Statement
sect1.para: Each California State University campus usses it own set of tools to develop content for their online delivery. In the past it was ok to use an HTML editor such as Adobe DreamWeaver to create content. Now faculty want immediate results and don't care as much about the underlying technology that allows to create content but want the content to be created with minimal effort and maximum results.
Students expectations have also evolved over the years. Where it was OK to just convert a Word Document to HTML now students want better quality on their instructional materials.
There are several tools available to help faculty in developing content both for their LMS content as well as for their web-based content. A sample of the tools is listed below:

I am not aware at this time whether any studies beyond the vendors' claims of compliance that confirm or refute the vendors claims. This project seeks to provide an initial knowledge base regarding content creation tools accessibility and as a springboard for Universities to select their tools knowing that they are accessible

sect1.title: Methodology
sect1.para: To avoid upsetting the balance at each other a survey will be conducted to determine which, if any, authoring tools are being used by each. This will provide an initial list of tools to evaluate.
Sample content authored in Microsoft Word 2003 and Microsoft Word 2007 will be input into each of the tools selected. The content will then be evaluated ussing standard accessibility tools.
In a parallel evaluation track the tools themselves will be evaluated for accessibility using JAWS

partintro.para: The following chapters describe case studies in the use of technology in higher education. They are all over the place and that's intentional: Technology in higher education should be varied and should challenge our assumptions and make us question our vision for our programs and the technologies that we use

The first chapter in this section describes the CSU Moodle Coalition, a collaborative effort from 3 CSU campuses in their Moodle efforts. It seeks to understand the choices the coalition members have made in the research implementation and now in their enterprise characteristics of their joint system

chapter.title: The Moodle experience
chapter.subtitle: Looking at Open Source for an LMS

sect1.title: Introduction and Background
sect1.para: Three CSU campuses are the leaders in implementing Moodle across the CSU: Humboldt State University, San Francisco State University and California State University, Monterey Bay. They have formed a Coalition to better support their development effort with Moodle.

Moodle itself has proved suprisingly popular since it was first released by Martin Dougiamas, an LMS administrator for an Australian University in August, 2002. Moodle, as many other Open Source projects, has developed a strong and healthy community around the LMS; this community provides for a support mechanism where the bugs are solved much quicker than in a propietary solution where they go through a close development process and a QA process where none of the customers get to see the work being done, only the results. In Moodle, the bugs are reported openly and there are multiple developers engaged in the process of supporting the community and fixing any bugs that may appear.

There is also the perceived cost of Moodle versus propietary software. While it is true that the license itself is considerably cheaper there are additional costs that are not always factored into this equation. You can choose to use Moodle and any Open Source software as is or "out of the box" with just a minimal knowledge of PHP, SQL databases and HTML and live with the limitations that the software may have for your particular institutional needs. Or you can choose to custmoize and enchance Moodle which means that you need one or more programmers who are experts in developing web applications in PHP, who have knowledge of web application architecture and who can dedicate significant time to developing the applications and functionality needed by the individual institution.

Either option entails risks and bennefits. In exploring how the 3 universities in the consortium dealt with this problems and others, we also explore how these problems may be answered at out institutions, either as part of the Moodle Coalition or idependently.

partintro.para: The following chapters are the conclusion of the themes covered earlier in this book. They address predictions of where we are going with technology itself, where we should be going with a Distance Learning program and where should our research emphasis be.

para.emphasis: More so than any other portion of this book, these chapters are my opinion and most definitely do not reflect those of CSU, Chico or the CSU system.

chapter.title: Vision and mission for a Distance Learning program
chapter.subtitle: What I think a Distance Learning program should be
chapter.para:
Based on all the research contained in the previous chapters what should a Distance Learning Program look like? What elements should we incorporate into this program? and, more importantly, how should we prepare such a program for the challenges ahead? In
I will provide a generic framework for analysis. Afterwards I will add additional considerations that don't really fit into the ADDIE model.
There are a few assumptions built into this model:

listitem.para:
Personel working in this project are generalist with an area of emphasis or interest:
While it's ok for people to manifest their preferences and interests, there is no reason for a request not to be completed because people are not familiar with policies and procedures be them technical or pedagogical.

Where possible, staff are exclusively assigned to the Distance Learning project:
I understand that this is unrealistic and that people usually take on, or are assigned, more than they should. However people working on a Distance Learning program should make that the emphasis of their work with other considerations being secondary to the Distance Learning effort

There is a set of tools and technologies that the team has agreed to support:
I am the first one to admit that I get distracted with the greatest and latest technology. But if we're going to provide program-wide support then we must agree on the technologies we are going to support.

There is a committment to the success of the team over individual achievements:
I will never discount the importance of individual success and satisfaction as long as it is not at the expense of the team's success and the overall mission of the Distance Learning program.

If any changes are to be made to an existing program they need to be agreed upon by the entire team
rather than implemented unilaterally by one member of the team.

sect1.title: Systematic Program Development
sect1.para: In order to develop a consistent Distance Learning program we need a systematic framework. I have chosen the ADDIE model to use as my design framework for a variety of reasons: it is the design model I am most familiar with; the steps in the process as familiar to most designers and they provide a framework that is easy to follow.

sect2.title: Analysis and Selection
sect2.para: Where we are and where we need to be are the first 2 questions that need to be asked. They seem easy questions to ask but the answers can be complicated.

The where are are question depends on who we ask. Students, faculty and administrators are likely to have different opinions on what the issues and solutions are. In order to get a better picture of what the program should really be like we should merge the opinions from each of the constituents groups; what may be acceptable for faculty may not be acceptable for students and vice versa. Perhaps qualifying the opinions of each group and listing them in numerical order (how many people expressed the same opinion)

I don't like surveying people unless it is deemed the best way to obtain information but in this situation a survey would be the best way to collect information about opinions and attitudes regarding the current program. If needed the survey can be followed up with targeted interviews to follow up on specific issues. This would allow us to collect aggregate data from our target population and only follow up with interviews where the survey data generated additional questions.

Knowing where we are today will allow us to better answer the question where we need to be. In analzying where we are going we need to consider the needs assessment from a pedagogical as well as a technical perspective. It is not only necessary to know what tools we should be using; we also need a solid pedagogical foundation as to why we will be using the tools we have chosen to support in the ways we are proposing to use them.

Those challenges that I consider most important from those posed by James L. Morrison and his team at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill ( Horizon ) have been highlighted in the lists below. It may be the case that these challenges are no longer relevant, that's for the team to decide. It does, however, raise interesting policy questions for any Distance Learning program. Some of the challenges and questions they posed:
Instructional Challenges

listitem.para: What topics lend themselves to distance education?
How can we create a community of online learners?
How do we maximize student-teacher, student-student interaction online?
How do we accommodate different learning styles and age ranges?
How do we set appropriate expectations for student work?

sect2.para: Management Challenges

listitem.para: What training do faculty members need to be successful in online teaching?
How do we provide equal access to distance learning?
What funding models should we adapt to support distance learning course development (cost-benefit analysis)?
How do we educate the decision makers on technology support?
How do we ascertain the goals of distance learning (efficiency, broad standards, access to quality education, reaching broader group of learners)?
How can we support the delivery of online education (e.g., registration, advising, library and laboratory facilities)?
What intellectual properties/copyright issues must be addressed?
How do we deal with the system when it fails?
How do we address privacy issues?
How do we address the respectability/image of distance education issue?
How do we develop balance in distance learning workloads compared to traditional workloads in clinical settings?
What is the relationship of online education to residential campus education?
How do we market distance education in a changing marketplace?
How do faculty attitudes towards distance learning impact developing distance education programs?

sect2.para: Assessment Challenges

listitem.para: How do we monitor/authenticate student performance in distance learning?
How do we assess effectiveness of online learning?

sect2.para:
We need to pay attention to what communities colleges are doing. Since universities get most of their students from community colleges it pays to pay attention to what they are doing in terms of Distance Learning. We need to prepare for what our students are using before they come to our school by either setting up their expectations accordingly or adopting the tools in use at other institutions to our processes and procedures. See
for more information

We should also pay attention to the tools available in the commercial/business sector and in higher education markets other than ours and our peer institutions and . One of the errors I see made over and over is that we limit ourselves to the tools other colleges and universities are using when it is sometimes true that comercial developer and large companies with their own training groups have developed better and easier to use tools.

One of the questions that is bound to be controversial is the choice between an empowerment and a service model.An empowerment model seeks to give instructors the tools necessary for them to complete their work-related projects on their own with only minor assistance. Service models, on the other hand, seek for staff to work with faculty as the primary developers of the content. The faculty is the Subject Matter Expert and the facilitator of the course they teach and, if they so choose, can collaborate with the development of the material but they are not expected to.

This discussion between empowerment and service becomes important when we set faculty's expectations and a Service Level Agreement. What are we expecting the faculty members, our primary customers, to do for themselves and what are we ready and willing to do for them?

Clear expectations are your friends when you're part of a project team. They clear the waters and they help to clarify any sort of confusion when it comes to who is supposed to do what. Use the force, young project team member, use the force and your SLA.

listitem.para: Analysis document containing results of faculty, student and administration surveys.
List of technologies to be evaluated and implemented. Preferably ranked in order of importance.
List of improvements to current processes and procedures along with new ideas on how to run operations and support faculty.
A rubric to use when selecting the tools to be used in the program. Ideally we should have one rubric for each area of the program we are implementing

sect2.title: Design & Development

mediaobject.caption: Be careful what you wish for.... You may get it.
mediaobject.alt: Be careful what you wish for.... You may get it. Dilbert cartoon

textobject.para: Be careful what you wish for.... You may get it. Dilbert cartoon

sect2.para: Designing a program is different and more challenging than developing tools but it includes processes, procedures and the tools that we need to implement these new programs.

Before we start work on designing and developing strategies for working on our new system, we need to, as a team, develop our mission statement. What we are about, what we seek to accomplish and the steps we will take to accomplish these objectives. Vision goes hand in hand with mission; while the mission statement talks about specific objectives, the mission talks about over-arching goals, what are the global things that we want to accomplish with the program and how will the mission, the people and the technology will help us get there.

The first step in deciding what the program is going to look like is to select the tools that we will use in this program. How do the tools we are looking at align with the mission statement; for example: How will the tools we are selecting will facilitate faculty's work on their online courses? This is where the rubrics developed as part of the analysis and selection process need to be used by selection committee with participation of all our constituents: students, faculty, technical staff and administrators. Under no circumstance should anything be done without faculty and administration input. For an example of what a tool selection process might look like, see
.

para.emphasis: What happens if none of the tools we propose are chosen by the committee?
What happens if the committee chooses more than 1 tool in a given category where the team was hoping to have only 1 chosen?

sect2.para: Hopefully this won't happen but the team needs to be prepared to address concerns like the ones above and others that may be raised over time. The team needs to establish a system were constituents communicate issues and concerns but, at the same time, they should establish a timeline with deadlines after which elements of the program are set and can no longer be changed.

Once the tools are decided on training, support and operational plans need to be designed and developed. These training interventions, in whatever form they take, should as close as possible to be delivered to potential customers. Care should be taken in developing multiple modalities of training for faculty. Long gone are the days where face-to-face instructor led training was the only realistic way to deliver training for faculty. Now it's becoming more and more usual to hear faculty requesting Just In Time training, consultations and tutorials to get help when and how they need it.

Support models to be implemented need to take into account the fact that programs being run have users from diverse geographical areas attending the same classes. The fact that there is not really a set schedule for attending the class present new challenges for a support team.

One area that has gained importance in the past couple years is accessibility. With Section 508, state and institutional mandates on accessibility it has become essential to both make old content accessible and to incorporate accessibility into all instructional material. How do we support accessibility from the beginning rather than have to retrofit content when needed? This is the time to develop an initial accessibility plan and discuss it with the campus accessibility and disabled student support team.

New operational models are needed to support these new technologies. How to use, run and support the software the team has selected to use and support. Processes need to be developed in, at least, three different areas: faculty support, student support and escalation to vendor. Any additional areas of support should be addressed at this point.

Encourage the team to develop multiple approaches to address these issues. Multiple perspectives are healthy and will encourage debate regarding best practices. It may also cover blind spots that may have been overlooked. It should not turn into a competition regarding whose approaches are better suited for a particular situation, that's for the team to decide. Nor should it turn into a personality conflict waiting to explode.

Communication is critical throughout the process but particularly so at the design and development stages. I am not partial to meetings. For the most part they are poorly run and become ground for the airing personal issues to the detriment of the team and the specific goals the team is pursuing. That is not to say that team meetings are not useful, when properly run and with the proper motivation. Lopp (2007) lists some of the good and not-so-good qualities of brainstorming and design meetings:

listitem.para: Are decisions being made? Is the group working well enough to make a decision? Yes? Good.
Are decisions being revisited? Is the group limber enough to go backwards to refine a previous decision? Even better.

Are decisions constantly being revisited? Ok, problem here. Your team has spun into creative nirvana. A good time to step back and apply a little structure to the process. Reviewing decisions to date is a good way to find structure and move forward. Oh, you werenâ€™t writing down the results of brainstorm meetings? Ooops. Start now.

Are basic truths about your design showing up? These are the gems of brainstorm. These are decisions which are made that define the basic design of your problem. Youâ€™ll know these when they show up, stand up to scrutiny, and eventually starting virally wandering the hallways.

Are holy shit moments occurring? Similar to the basic truth discovery, but louder and infrequent. "HOLY SHIT, we're completely wrong." Holy shits are disruptive, but are a good sign a limber creative process.

Is the to do list growing or shrinking? If youâ€™re early on in the design phase, it should be growing. If youâ€™re getting close to the end of your design phase, it better be getting smaller.... Better is the enemy of done and if itâ€™s your project, you need to draw a line on what topics/ideas you intend to tackle and stick to it.

sect2.para: The twin qualities of a meeting are creativity and accountability. It is not enough to expect or demand creativity. The team needs to be accountable to administration and to our constituents. We have to remain flexible to deal with changes and the only way to do that is by having a thinking team. One that can react when the situation demands, but also a team that retains the capability of think a problem through, either as it's happening or afterwards as it is debriefed. The best way to put it is in the quote below:

blockquote.para: ... but Google gets two wins out of the program. First, some of the projects create value for the company. Itâ€™s probably one in five, but thatâ€™s not the real value. Google is creating a culture of thinking by allowing their employees to wander about and bump into shit.

I donâ€™t know what you do and I donâ€™t know what you build. I am certain that if you donâ€™t demonstrate creative thinking in what you build, youâ€™re screwed because you, your team, and your product will stagnate. Kicking off brainstorming meetings are a tricky proposition. They are poorly defined, hard to run, and harder to measure. What comes out of these meetings might be brilliance or stupidityâ€¦ the difference between the two is magnificently slim. Good luck. ( Lopp 2007 )

sect2.para: Once we have all our training developeed and our procedures in place it is time to run a pilot. This pilot should be kept small; we are evaluating our training, policies, procedures and support systems, not releasing the program to the whole world. I'd reccomend anywhere for 5 to 8 faculty members teaching 1 course section each at most for an initial program.

I include a pilot during the design and development phase because it gives us time to make changes without impacting our timeline too much. It is the iterative nature of the program. We tested something and then we make any changes to the elements of the program based on the results of the test. This is also different than a pilot run during the implementation phase. They are both testing different areas of the program and should be treated accordingly

Documents indicating initial workflow, processes and procedures to support faculty and students
Document outlining processes, procedures and workflows to escalate issues to vendors
Internal communication workflows and protocols
Basic training workshops sketched and delivered at least once to a pilot group

sect2.title: Implementation

para.emphasis: There's never time to do it right but there's always time to do it over

sect2.para: Once we have the blueprints created during the design and development stages it is now time to get busy with implementing the policies, procedures and systems we need to have in place for our second pilot run.

Training should be taking its final form by now; mostly polish and changes based on feedback from pilot training participants. We need to make sure that training in its final form is ready to go when we first start soliciting instructors for our large pilot and formative evaluation.

As training solidifies, the policy and procedures aspect should also be finalized. The team should be spending time fleshing out the training outlines and to begin in depth conversations with any group that interacts with them in any capacity to make sure that "we are all in the same page." There is nothing worst than having your very carefully thought out plan nixed by an outside group because it involves too much work from their end without a significant return on investment.

Once we call implementation done we should be looking at finished products; fully agreed upon processes and procedures and line of communications ready and available for two-way communication with all our stake holders; training in its final form (or as final as training ever gets).

listitem.para: Documents indicating final workflow, processes and procedures to support faculty and students
Document outlining final processes, procedures and workflows to escalate issues to vendors
Internal communication workflows and protocols agreed upon by the team and those stake holders directly involved in supporting Distance Learning
Final training workshops incorporating the feedback from the training pilot group

sect2.title: Evaluation

sect2.para: From my perspective there is no better tool than evaluation for program improvement. The feedback we gather from our constitutents and stakeholders is the best way to keep a pulse on the team's status and overall program health.

I also want to emphasize the differences between the formative and summative evaluations: Formative evaluations test policies, procedures and workflows while summative evaluation seeks feedback on the program itself.
It is only through this combination of feedback gathered periodically that we can hope to have a competitive distance learning program.

sect3.title: Formative Evaluations
sect3.para: I am a strong believer in continual improvement and rapid prototyping
Continual improvement means that we're never really done with a project; periodically we evaluate the current status of the project and make changes according to the evaluation results.

Rapid Prototyping (
) proposes an iterative design where the phase of design, development and implementation in the ADDIE model are accelerated in order for the audience to provide feedback over a completed product and additional iterations of a project as needed to correct problems found by the feedback providers.

The different aspects of the project need to be evaluated by all constituents: faculty, students and support staff. The main difference between these evaluation groups is how often does the team solicit their feedback. Faculty and students' feedback should be solicited, at least, once a semester or academic term. This will allow the team to provide continual improvement to our customers

Formative evaluation from the technical and support staffs should happen as often as needed to maintain proper operation. I would suggest weekly to start and move on to bi-weekly or even montly if the traffic slows down enough. It is important not to stop the feedback look just becasue there are no problems.

sect3.title: Summative Evaluations
sect3.para: Summative evaluations tend to not to be conducted as often as the formative evaluations. I also call these occurrences "program reviews" where project staff, faculty and administration gather together to evaluate the program and suggest/propose/demand changes.
A well run program review meeting or meetings (I think this process should be done over time) is to modify the program as needed to

Source:
http://edutechwiki.unige.ch/en/ADDIE

A markup language developed by the World Wide Web Consortium as a complement or replacement for HTML. XML is widely used in the bussines world as an information exchange format. In the education work it has primarily been used for description of information in SCORM and IMS specifications.

In 1997, IMS came into existence as a project within the National Learning Infrastructure Initiative of EDUCAUSE. While IMS got its start with a focus on higher education, the specifications published to date as well as ongoing projects address requirements in a wide range of learning contexts, including of course K-12 schools and corporate and government training.

IMS GLC is a global, nonprofit, member association that provides leadership in shaping and growing the learning and educational technology industries through collaborative support of standards, innovation, best practice and recognition of superior learning impact.

IMS GLC represents more than 100 Contributing Members, Subscriber organizations and Common Cartridge Alliance participants. These participant organizations come from every sector of the global learning community. They include hardware and software vendors, educational institutions, publishers, government agencies, systems integrators, multimedia content providers, and other consortia. IMS provides a neutral forum in which members work together to advocate the use of technology to support and transform education and learning.

Training that is delivered as needed to the participant rather than scheduled in advance. Just In Time Training is primarily used in Performance Improvement to correct a problem that needs specific instruction for its resoilution
Producing or conveying only the items that are needed by the next process when they are needed and in the quantity needed. Can even be used between facilities or companies. Source: Lean Advisors

You can download and use it on any computer you have handy (including webhosts), yet it can scale from a single-teacher site to a 50,000-student University.
